prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA because I want my hair fixed, for free, by the hairdresser?
[What I showed her](http://imgur.com/KmuiLRL)


[What I got](http://imgur.com/gEiWAi4)


I asked my stylist to do a light brown rose gold, and emphasized that I wanted it a light brown, warm color.

I showed her the picture more than a week in advance of the appointment so she had time to get any colors she didn’t have. 

I told her multiple times I wanted a light brown.  I know you can’t perfectly match the picture, but I think I made it obvious I wanted more brown than red in my hair.  I would have been fine without the rose tint.  My hair was bleach blonde to begin with.

She’s going to try to fix it but I don’t think I should have to pay, this is clearly not what I asked for.  Am I the asshole?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The person is asking if they're the asshole for wanting a free fix from their hairdresser because the hair color wasn't what they asked for. They showed a reference image of a light brown rose gold, emphasized wanting a light brown, warm color, and mentioned they wanted more brown than red. Their hair was bleach blonde to start with, and the result came out more red. The hairdresser is going to try to fix it, but the person thinks they shouldn't have to pay for the fix.

First, they provided clear instructions and showed the reference image in advance. The hairdresser didn't follow the instructions accurately. The result was not what was asked for. Customers typically expect the service to meet their specified request. If the stylist didn't meet that expectation despite clear communication, it's on the stylist. The fact that the client emphasized the preference multiple times and gave advance notice makes the stylist's mistake more clear. The client isn't in the wrong for expecting a correct job and seeking a free fix. So the answer should be B (the author is not in the wrong).
